question: I understand something better after I
optionB: think it through

question: I would rather be considered
optionB: innovative.

question: When I think about what I did yesterday, I am most likely to get
optionB: words.

question: I tend to
optionA: understand details of a subject but may be fuzzy about its overall structure.
optionB: understand the overall structure but may be fuzzy about details.

question: When I am learning something new, it helps me to
optionB: think about it.

question: If I were a teacher, I would rather teach a course
optionA: that deals with facts and real life situations.
optionB: that deals with ideas and theories.

question: I prefer to get new information in
optionB: written directions or verbal information.

question: Once I understand
optionA: all the parts, I understand the whole thing.
optionB: the whole thing, I see how the parts fit.

question: In a study group while working on difficult material, I am more likely to
optionB: sit back and listen.

question: I find it easier
optionB: to learn concepts.

question: In a book with lots of pictures and charts, I am likely to
optionA: look over the pictures and charts carefully.
optionB: focus on the written text.

question: When I solve maths problems
optionA: I usually work my way to the solutions one step at a time.
optionB: I often just see the solutions but then have to struggle to figure out the steps to get to them.

question: In classes I have taken,
optionA: I have usually got to know many of the students.
optionB: I have rarely got to know many of the students.

question: In reading non-fiction, I prefer
optionA: something that teaches me new facts or tells me how to do something.
optionB: something that gives me new ideas to think about.

question: I like teachers
optionA: who put a lot of diagrams on the whiteboard.
optionB: who spent a lot of time explaining.

question: When I'm analysing a story or a novel
optionA: I think of the incidents and try to put them together to figure out the themes.
optionB: I just know what the themes are when I finish reading and then I have to go back and find the incidents that demonstrate them.

question: When I start a homework problem, I am more likely to
optionA: start working on the solution immediately.
optionB: try to fully understand the problem first.

question: I prefer the idea of
optionB: theory.

question: I remember best
optionB: what I hear.

question: It is more important to me that an instructor
optionA: lays out the material in clear sequential steps.
optionB: give me an overall picture and relate the material to other subjects.

question: I prefer to study
optionB: alone.

question: I am more likely to be considered
optionA: careful about the details of my work.
optionB: creative about how to do my work.

question: When I get directions to a new place, I prefer
optionB: written instructions.

question: I learn
optionA: at a fairly regular pace. If I studied hard, I would "get it."
optionB: in fits and starts. I would be totally confused and then suddenly it all "clicks."

question: I would rather first
optionB: think about how I was going to do it.

question: When I am reading for enjoyment, I would like writers to
optionB: say things in creative, interesting ways.

question: When I see a diagram or sketch, I am most likely to remember
optionB: what the instructor had said about it.

question: When considering a body of information, I am more likely to
optionA: focus on details and miss the big picture.
optionB: try to understand the big picture before getting into the details.

question: I more easily remember
optionB: something I have thought a lot about.

question: When I had to perform a task, I prefer to
optionA: master one way of doing it.
optionB: come up with new ways of doing it.

question: When someone is showing me data, I prefer
optionB: text summarizing the results.

question: When writing a paper, I am more likely to
optionA: work on (think about or write) the beginning of the paper and progress forward.
optionB: work on (think about or write) different parts of the paper and then order them.

question: When I have to work on a group project, I first want to
optionA: have a "group brainstorming" where everyone contributes ideas.
optionB: brainstorm individually and then come together as a group to compare ideas.

question: I consider it higher praise to call someone
optionB: imaginative.

question: When I meet people at a party, I am more likely to remember
optionB: what they said about themselves.

question: When I am learning a new subject, I prefer to
optionA: stay focused on that subject, learning as much about it as I can.
optionB: try to make connections between that subject and related subjects.

question: I am more likely to be considered
optionB: reserved.

question: I prefer courses that emphasise
optionB: abstract material (concepts, theories).

question: For entertainment, I would rather
optionB: read a book.

question: Some teachers start their lessons with an outline of what they will cover. Such outlines are
optionB: very helpful to me.

question: The idea of doing homework in groups, with one grade for the entire group,
optionB: does not appeal to me.

question: When I do long calculations,
optionA: I tend to repeat all my steps and check my work carefully.
optionB: I find checking my work tiresome and have to force myself to do it.

question: I tend to picture places I have been to
optionB: with dificulty and without much detail.

question: When solving problems in a group, I would be more likely to
optionA: think of the steps in the solution process.
optionB: think of possible consequences or applications of the solution in a wide range of areas.
